content: The "Delaware River Protection Act of 2005" requires notifying the Coast Guard of objects released into navigable waters of the United States under the Ports and Waterways Safety Act. The Delaware River Protection Act of 2005 mandates immediate notification to the Secretary and the Secretary of the Army of any release into US navigable waters that creates an obstruction. Notifications cannot be used against the individual in criminal cases, except for perjury or false statements. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to adjust liability limits for tank vessels, specifying different amounts per gross ton for incidents occurring in 2005, 2006, and 2007 onwards. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to adjust liability limits for tank vessels based on gross tonnage for incidents in 2005, 2006, and beyond. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to adjust liability limits for tank vessels based on gross tonnage for incidents in 2005, 2006, and beyond. The amendment includes increasing the liability limit from $2,000,000 to $2,500,000 and adjusting limits every 3 years based on the Consumer Price Index. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to adjust liability limits for tank vessels based on gross tonnage for incidents in 2005, 2006, and beyond. The amendment includes increasing the liability limit from $2,000,000 to $2,500,000 and adjusting limits every 3 years based on the Consumer Price Index. Thereafter, adjust the limits on liability specified in subsection (a) to reflect significant increases in the Consumer Price Index. The Philadelphia Area Committee must update the Philadelphia Area Contingency Plan to include data on environmentally sensitive areas of the Delaware River and Delaware Bay. Additionally, amendments are made to the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 regarding submerged oil removal. The Undersecretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere, along with the Coast Guard Commandant, will establish a program to detect, monitor, and evaluate the environmental effects of submerged oil. This program includes developing methods to remove, disperse, or diminish submerged oil, improving models for predicting its fate, and developing techniques to detect and monitor it. The Secretary of Commerce must submit a report within 3 years of the enactment of the Delaware River amendments. The Secretary of Commerce, in conjunction with the Coast Guard Commandant, will conduct a demonstration project to remove submerged oil. $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2010 for this purpose. The Coast Guard Commandant, in collaboration with the Secretary of Commerce, will conduct a demonstration project to develop technologies for removing submerged oil from navigable waters. $2,000,000 is authorized annually from 2006 to 2010 for this purpose. "Sec. 7002. Submerged oil program. SEC. 6. DELAWARE RIVER AND BAY OIL SPILL ADVISORY COMMITTEE." The Delaware River and Bay Oil Spill Advisory Committee is established to make recommendations on improving prevention and response to oil spills in the Delaware River and Bay. The Committee must hold its first meeting within 60 days of member appointments. The Delaware River and Bay Oil Spill Advisory Committee consists of 15 members with expertise in transportation, equipment, and vessel navigation in the Delaware River and Bay. Three members are from port authorities overseeing operations on the Delaware River, including the Port of Wilmington and the South Jersey Port Corporation. The Committee must meet at the Chairman's call after the initial meeting within 60 days of member appointments. The Delaware River and Bay Oil Spill Advisory Committee consists of 15 members with expertise in transportation, equipment, and vessel navigation in the Delaware River and Bay. Members include representatives from port authorities, organizations operating tugs or barges, shipping companies, oil refineries, environmental interests, State-licensed pilots, and labor organizations. The Delaware River and Bay Oil Spill Advisory Committee consists of 15 members with expertise in transportation, equipment, and vessel navigation in the area. Members include representatives from port authorities, organizations operating tugs or barges, shipping companies, oil refineries, environmental interests, State-licensed pilots, and labor organizations. The Commandant appoints members after soliciting nominations, and the Committee elects a Chairman and Vice Chairman at its first meeting. Members serve without pay, except for officers or employees of the United States. Members of the Delaware River and Bay Oil Spill Advisory Committee serve without pay, except for officers or employees of the United States. They may receive travel expenses as authorized by law. The Committee will terminate one year after the appointment of its members. SEC. 7. MARITIME FIRE AND SAFETY ACTIVITIES amended the Maritime Transportation Security Act of 2002 by increasing funding to $1,500,000 and updating the section title.
